Montassier *, J.M. Dumas, P. Granger, J. Barbier U.R.A. CNRS 350 Laboratoire de Chimie 4, 40 Avenue du Recteur Pineau, 86022 Poitiers Cedex, France Received 13 May 1994; revised 21 September 1994; accepted 22 September 1994 Abstract Degradations and cyclodehydration of polyols in aqueous solution were studied on copper deposited on charcoal unmodified or modified by addition of chloride and a second metal (Pt or Au). These catalysts had properties very close to those of Raney copper based catalysts. Their deactivation was studied in a dynamic flow three-phase reactor, Sintering of copper particles, surface oxidation and copper(I) hydroxide dehydration were responsible for the deactivation of the unmodified Cu/C. In the cases of modified Cu/C, decrease of the cyclodehydration selectivity was attributed to the loss of chloride. Addition of chloride ions to the polyol solution to be converted increased the cyclodehydration selectivity but strongly decreased the activity. Keywords: Copper/charcoal; Cyclodehydration; Deactivation; Erythritol; Glucitol; Glycerol; Polyol conversion 1. Introduction Copper catalysts are able to hydro-dehydrogenate carbon-oxygen bonds [ 1 ] . Degradations of polyols in aqueous phase to lower polyols on Raney copper from 493 to 533 K under 1 to 4 MPa of hydrogen originate from this property [2] and not from direct hydrogenolysis as in the case of Ru for example. Thus, for instance, with copper, glycerol is converted to 1,2-propanediol and ethylene glycol; glucitol (sorbitol) is partially converted into glycerol and 1,2-propanediol. Degradation reactions (C-O and C-C cleavages) arise from the bifunctional properties of copper whose surface is made of metallic copper and of copper(I) hydroxide. Metallic copper would be responsible for hydro-dehydrogenation reactions and surface hydroxyls such as copper(1) hydroxide for dehydroxylation, retroClaisen and retro-Michael reactions. Degradation mechanisms of polyols on copper catalysts. `OH' are surface hydroxyl species. Bimetals based on Raney copper were studied for these reactions [3-6]. The basic metal modification was done by oxido-reduction between the Raney copper and a chlorinated salt of the second metal. This technique gave bimetals having the general formula: Cu-M-x where M indicates the nature of the added metal (Pt, Au, Pd, Ru) and x is the atomic loading as the atomic percentage of the superficial copper (metallic and Cu) of the basic catalyst. When the precursor salt used was a chloride, the bimetals contained chloride. It appeared that if x > 20%, all superficial hydroxyl groups were removed and thus degradation reactions were completely absent. On the other hand, sites CupMbCU the exact nature of which could not be determined, and sites CuCI and Cu-M were created and catalyzed the cyclodehydration (CDOH) of polyols made of 4 carbon atoms or more. Fig. 2 shows the suggested mechanism (from electrophilic copper) and the products obtained from erythritol and glucitol. The whole study was conducted in a static reactor (autoclave). It appeared that the chlorinated bimetals, very selective for CDOH, lose some chloride during the reaction. Moreover, when these catalysts were used again with a new polyol solution, degradation products appeared concurrently with the cyclodehydration products [6]. Thus the catalyst is modified during the reaction. The aim of this work was to study this modification. The behaviours of copper and of some bimetals based on copper were studied for polyol conversion in a dynamic flow three-phase reactor. Catalysts The basic catalyst, Cu/C, was prepared with a charcoal from CECA (ACL 45, 1400 m2 g-') as cylindric grains (1.5 mm in diameter, 3 mm in length). To eliminate any sulfur it was reduced under hydrogen at 1273 K and oxidized by nitric acid (2 M at 373 K). Then it was impregnated with aqueous copper nitrate by evaporation to dryness. The reduction was done under a hydrogen stream for 3 h at 573 K after raising the temperature at a rate of 2 K min'. After cooling under nitrogen the catalyst was stored in air. Its copper loading, determined by chemical analysis, was 11.6 wt.-%. The copper metallic area measured by nitrous oxide decomposition at ambient temperature was 28 m2 g-' Cu, assuming a mean surface density of 1.46 - 10'9 copper atoms per m2 [ 7 ] . X-ray diffraction (XRD) only showed lines of metallic copper crystallites whose diameter was close to 72 A. The bimetals Cu-M-x/C were prepared as previously described for Raney copper [ 3 ] . Briefly, the desired amount of Cu/C is reduced at 573 K by hydrogen and cooled under nitrogen in a glass vessel in which 100 ml of an aqueous solution of the salt of the second metal (H2PtC16 or HAuC14) was added at ambient temperature. The slurry was mixed by bubbling nitrogen through for 1 h. The reaction was complete and very rapid as in the case of Raney copper and can be written as: nCu+ 2M"+ - nCu2+ + 2Ms and nCus + M" + --> nCu2 + + MS according to the standard oxido-reduction potentials: Cu2+ /Cu = 0.34 V; Cu2+ / Cu + -0.15 V; Pt4+/Pt=0.74 V; Au4+/Au=0.99 V. Three bimetals were thus prepared. Their compositions are given in Table 1. All the bimetallic catalysts have blended chloride. 2.2. Reactions The reactions in a static reactor were performed with crushed catalysts (grain size: 0.04-0.1 mm). The procedure and analysis of the reaction products (HPLC) were described previously [ 2,3 ] . Dynamic flow reactor. The three-phase dynamic reactor ( up flow) is described in Fig. 3. Hydrogen was introduced at the bottom of the reactor through a reducing valve and a flow controller ( Brooks ) . Simultaneously, the nitrogen-degassed aqueous solution of polyol was introduced through a high-pressure pump. The reactor was a stainless tube (LD. 17 mm, length 650 mm). The reactants were cooled and separated under pressure in a condenser. The gases escaped through a pressure controller ( Brooks) that kept constant the total pressure that is the sum of the water pressure in the reactor at its working temperature and of the desired hydrogen pressure. The liquid phase in the condenser escaped through a solenoid valve driven from a level probe placed in the condenser. Finally, gases and liquids were separated at room pressure and temperature. The loading of the reactor was achieved by diluting it ( near 50 vol.-% ) with carborundum. The first and last stages of the reactor were also filled with carborundum. After flushing with nitrogen and then with hydrogen at atmospheric pressure, the temperature was raised ( 2 K min') up to 573 K and kept at this value for 3 h to reduce the catalyst. After that, the reactor was cooled to the working temperature (493 to 533 K), the flow of polyol solution (0.11 M) was established ( 50 to 110 ml h') and then the hydrogen pressure (partial pressure: 0.1 to 4 MPa) and flow (61 h-') were adjusted. The results will be presented as the conversion level (percentage of converted polyol) and/or as the activity referred to the weight of catalyst (mol h-' g-' cat) or of copper (mol h-' g-' Cu). Selectivities are the molar percentages of the obtained products referred to the amount of converted polyol. 236 C. Montassier et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 121(1995) 231-2O 3. Results 3.1. After 9 h of work time, a glucitol solution without any sodium chloride was converted: the catalyst activity increased as the conversion reached almost 60% but cyclodehydration selectivity decreased down to 28% (Fig. 9b) . After 25 h of total work time, sodium chloride was again added to the glucitol solution (Fig. 9c). (5% of conversion). 4. Discussion The monometallic Cu/C catalyst is initially made of metallic copper crystallites without any well crystallized copper oxide. Their behaviours for the conversion of polyols are the same as those of Raney copper in aqueous medium at 493-533 K under hydrogen pressure. As an example, in the static reactor and under the same experimental conditions, the initial activities and selectivities are of the same magnitude. Thus, the mechanisms of the degradation reactions and the nature of the sites on which they occur are probably the same: simple or multiple hydro-dehydrogenations of C-0 bonds on the metallic copper, dehydroxylation and retroClaisen from nucleophilic action of adsorbed hydroxyls, probably as copper(1) hydroxide, as shown in Fig. 1. The modification of the Cu/C catalyst used in the dynamic flow reactor when treated with water with or without a polyol conversion reveals: - sintering of the metallic copper, - oxidation of copper with appearance of a well crystallized phase of copper(1) oxide, . - formation of cyclodehydration sites. The main part of the sintering occurs quickly in the first hour of a run in the dynamic flow reactor. The sintering mechanism was studied in the case of copper deposited on silica [ 8 ] and seems to be suitable to this work. Thus the small copper particles much more oxidizable than the big ones, would give oxide or hydroxide of copper(1). Unstable, they would be solubilized. However, in our experimental conditions, they may undergo a disproportionation [9] as: 2Cu+aq ;F?t CuCu2+aq (1) The growth of the remaining copper on the charcoal surface is explained by reaction (1) but also by the adsorption of the Cu2+ species on the bigger particles and their reduction by even: 242 C. Montassier et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 121 (1995) 231-244 -the metallic copper itself: Cue+aq+Cus+H20 ;i::!: 2Cu(OH)s+2H+ (2) -the adsorbed hydrogen on metallic copper: Cue+aq+ZHOs -- Cu, +2H+ (3) When the Cu/C catalyst was treated by water under a low hydrogen pressure (0.1 MPa), a loss of copper was observed. In this case reaction (3) would be very slow. If reaction (2) is also rather slow, then part of the Cue+aq ions would be drawn off by the water flow. On the other hand, if the hydrogen pressure is higher (1.7 MPa or more), reaction (3) would be sufficiently fast to avoid any notable loss of copper. According to this mechanism, copper(I) hydroxide and metallic copper would be present at the copper surface, but the amount of metallic species would increase as the hydrogen pressure is increased, decreasing the amount of copper(l) hydroxide species. In such a case the rates of the degradation reactions would be slowed down all the more as hydrogen inhibits thermodynamically the dehydrogenation steps (Fig. 1) . On the other hand it was observed that the residual activities for glycerol and erythritol degradations were higher at 4.0 MPa than at 1.0 MPa of hydrogen pressure. This result may be understood if it is assumed that the rate determining factor is the net metallic copper surface available for adsorption of the polyol molecules. However, concerning the selectivity for glycerol conversion, an increase of the hydrogen pressure inhibits the double dehydrogenation (necessary for the production of ethylene glycol through the retro-Claisen reaction) more than the simple dehydrogenation (leading to 1,2-propanediol through the dehydroxylation). As a result it was observed that more 1,2-propanediol was obtained at a higher hydrogen pressure. The deactivation seems to proceed continuously, probably because of copper oxidation. In parallel, during erythritol and glucitol conversions, cyclodehydration products appeared. Their formation does not require any dehydrogenation reaction (Fig. 2) but involves electrophilic sites absent on the initial catalyst surface. As copper(l) oxide appears during the catalyst deactivation (Table 3) it may be assumed that this oxide would be the catalyst of this reaction according to the scheme: Ha+ c-, ~c H s s-o `o0 o,H s o + c, --c 0 Cu CU Cu Cu The formation of this copper(l) oxide can come from the slow and gradual dehydration of copper(l) hydroxide: 2CuOH - CU20 + H20 (5 ) C. Montassier et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 121(1995) 231-2O 243 Copper deposited on charcoal can undergo the same modification as for Raney copper by oxidoreduction with the salt of a more noble metal such as platinum or gold. The bimetals obtained are as selective for cyclodehydration as those prepared from Raney copper when used only once in the static reactor. However, they lost some chloride necessary for the cyclodehydration to be highly selective. This is well evidenced by the experiments carried out in the dynamic reactor (Fig. 8a) where the degradation reactions appeared as the catalyst lost chloride. However, the effect of chloride ion addition to the glucitol solution is interesting. According to a previous work [ 3 ] , the high cyclodehydration selectivity of Raney copper was attributed to Cu-M, Cu-Cl and overall Cup Mb-Clc species (M modifier metal, a, b, c unknown). Hydrolysis of these species, for instance in the case of CuCl: CuCl+HZ0 -- CuOH+H++Cl- (6) regenerates surface hydroxyl groups able to degrade dehydrogenated polyols if metallic copper is still present at the catalyst surface. This reaction (6) is assumed to be faster than (5) . The remaining cyclodehydration observed may come from the residual CuCl species or from the Cu-M sites or from the formation of CU20 sites according to Eq. (5) as for the Cu/C catalyst. The addition of chloride ions to the glucitol solution shifts the equilibrium (6) to the left, restoring more cyclodehydration sites. However the whole restoration of CuCl species could not be reached with the chloride concentration used (0.2 M) and chloride ions had a strong inhibiting effect on the overall rate of glucitol conversion (Fig. 9b, c). Qualitatively, this effect may be a poisoning of the metallic copper surface necessary for the adsorption of the polyol molecules and their dehydrogenation, and so, their degradation. This poisoning would be a reversible adsorption of chloride ions without significant formation of CuCl species active for cyclodehydroxylation. 5. Conclusion The behaviour of Cu/C catalyst for polyol degradations is very similar to those of Raney copper. In a dynamic flow reactor it was deactivated first by a quick sintering that involved oxidation of small copper particles, dissolution, readsorption on big particles and reduction. This catalyst further deactivated because of surface oxidation and dehydration of copper(I) hydroxide (responsible for the degradations) to copper(I) oxide. This oxide seems to be responsible for the gradual appearance of cyclodehydration products in the cases of erythritol and glucitol. The Cu/C catalyst could be modified by oxido-reduction to give bimetallic catalysts Cu-Pt and Cu-Au containing chloride. These catalysts were initially as selective for polyol cyclodehydration as were the modified Raney copper catalysts: no degradation reactions appeared because all hydroxyls of the copper(I) hydroxide species were replaced by chloride. This copper(I) chloride seems to be the main 244 C. Montassier et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 121(1995) 231-2O active phase for cyclodehydration. In the dynamic flow reactor the catalyst deactivated and degradation reactions took place because of partial hydrolysis of the chloride they contained, restoring copper(I) hydroxide and leading to a decrease of the cyclodehydration selectivity. This hydrolysis could be restricted but not completely eliminated by addition of chloride to the initial polyol solution. Unfortunately the activity was strongly decreased probably because of a poisoning effect of these added chloride ions, the cause of which could not be well understood. References [ 1 ] N.W. Degradations and cyclodehydration of polyols in aqueous solution were studied on copper deposited on charcoal unmodified or modified by addition of chloride and a second metal (Pt or Au). These catalysts had properties very close to those of Raney copper based catalysts. Their deactivation was studied in a dynamic flow three-phase reactor. Sintering of copper particles, surface oxidation and copper(I) hydroxide dehydration were responsible for the deactivation of the unmodified Cu/C. In the cases of modified Cu/C, decrease of the cyclodehydration selectivity was attributed to the loss of chloride.
